comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
The grey seal is by far the larger of the two species found in Ireland and is distinguished by a straight horse-like snout when compared with the short dog-like nose of the harbour seal. The colour pattern on grey seal coats tends to appear as a series of dark or light blotches on a light to dark grey background while harbour seals have a more finely speckled coat, which may be brown to grey in colour.

I think we have a  Grey in this photo

comment.author: 18885703@N00
comment._content: ...my expert friend tells me that the centre chap's firearm is a Sharps single shot percussion .52 cal carbine, which gives it a vintage of mid-19C

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Earlier than this photo, but here's an 1845 account of a huge seal shot by some gentlemen staying at Achill. "Some idea may be formed of the size of the animal from the fact that the skin of the tail alone is sufficiently large to make a tobacco pouch". When the carcass was displayed at Westport market, a Ballycroy man identified the seal as "Shawn a thra wee" or "Jack of the yellow strand",

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Grey Seal by [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75753392@N07]

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/paulajjames/7987906156/]

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Later than the photo, but in 1894, a letter from a F. W. Crossley to Freeman's discusses ways of alleviating the "ill-conditioned and impoverished state of the Achilleese" by promoting tourism following the "recent lamentable disaster" and states that "within the area of the island (33,283 acres) one can enjoy unrivalled mountain climbing, sea bathing, boating, sea and lake fishing, seal shooting &c, &c". Adverts for coastal properties elsewhere also highlight the quality of the seal shooting.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I expect the three gents pictured did not require the same fortitude which Orcadian James Harcus displayed in 1865 while landing his prey. A Bold Seal-Stalker (Dundee Courier and Argus via the Orkney Herald).

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Did the bould James do a bit of spoofing in his time?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Apart from the above-mentioned incident, which also appeared over the course of the following two weeks in The Morning Post, The Nottinghamshire Guardian and The Bradford Observer, there's a mention 34 years later of a James Harcus taking part in Kirkaldy Swimming Club's aquatic sports day in front of 3000 spectators. He was placed 3rd in the obstacle race. And a John Harcus won the "Neat Swimming" event. So the Harcus family seems to have specialised in (to our ears) bizarre-sounding swimming events.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
